ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course has helped me to develop and improve my communication skills by engaging in weekly dialogue with peers and performing reordered presentations which aided in building my confidence with public speaking. Moreover, I learned a great deal of knowledge about the Islamic culture and Arabic language.

I have not only learned the Arabic language at a fluency level far higher than I would have anticipated, but I also fell in love with the language and its roots even more. Ive learned grammatical, vocabulary, speaking, etc. Being able to be in a classroom environment with such likeminded individuals was so beautiful.
I learned useful and more advanced grammar in MSA than I previously did in ARBC 110.
Further understanding of elementary Arabic, conversational skills, reading comprehension, and cultural knowledge of the Arab world.
I improved my skills for reading, listening, speaking, and writing in Arabic

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course has no weaknesses. Professor Elbousty is one of the best professors at Yale. He is highly compassionate and pushes each student in his class to reach their fullest potential.

This course didnt have weaknesses. I absolutely love Professor Elbousty and his teaching style. Hes an extremely intellectual person & knows the Arabic language very well. His passion for teaching is such a high in the course. He engages his students so well & makes everyone feel heard and smart (even if sometimes we arent). I cant wait to take literature courses with him in the future.
The course's biggest strength is the instructor. It also has a great use of the textbook and I like the way it was scheduled so that we still had some, but not a lot, of work on days we didn't meet.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the variety of activities and class types throughout the week made it a lot easier to not get sick of class unlike those with the same lectures every two days. I also think that seminars were the way to go with Zoom, I felt way more engaged in my small classes than I ever did in Econ 115 and 116 - I don't know who decided to eliminate the seminar versions of those classes, but I have a bone to pick with them. Having group projects - with the groups assigned by our professor - also built into our class a way to get to know our classmates, which I really appreciated with the Zoom format and having been a remote student this semester. I also liked the consistency of assignments and clarity of instructions which accompanied them, I always knew what was expected of me which was a big deal when you couldn't easily just pop into your professor's office or office hours and ask a quick question.
Fortunately everything went well and ran smooth in this course. Zoom has been a great tool for virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone interested in learning the Arabic language. I entered this course with NO prior knowledge. After one year of working with Professor Elbousty, I have developed communication skills that will enable me to interact in the Islamic world. Most importantly, Professor Elbousty creates a safe space for students to explore their intellectual curiosities while learning a new language. I met some great people and forged long-standing friendships while taking this course.
Yes, the course is integral to learning Arabic to a proficient level and is very well organized.

Absolutely. I made some of my best friends in this course even though we were on Zoom just because of the energy of Professor Elbousty. Also Bayan and Salma were outstanding TAs. The course is definitely a lot of work, but you will get out of it exactly what you put in. Ive loved every minute of learning Arabic. Its so rewarding.

Definitely! Arabic is a hard language to learn, but because of that looking back on your progress is honestly astonishing, and it means that Arabic is a fairly small community, which makes it a really amazing one. Everyone I met taking Arabic this year was just a lovely person, and the sense of community in our class with Professor Elbousty was strong. And like I said, it's a really rewarding language to study.
I would highly recommend this course to another student. The Arabic language is intimidating to want to learn but this course makes it very doable.
If they want to learn Arabic, of course.
Definitely. The Arabic language is very fascinating and I've greatly enjoyed learning it under the amazing teaching team I had this past year.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to the the live virtual lectures, Professor Elbousty provided a recorded audio for students to refer back to after class which I found to be helpful. We also met with our TA once a week to review material from lecture and to ask questions about concepts that were challenging.
We also had group work days and discussion section!

This semester we had three live seminars per week (MWF), section with our TA once a week (T), group projects to work on once a week (Th), and recorded grammar lectures for us to watch on our own time once a week.
We used other online platforms to do listening exercises at our own pace.
